Repeat this story with no changes whatsoever: There was once a cat by the name of Thomas. This was no ordinary cat, however. Thomas was special. Not only was he wise beyond his years, but he also had the power to speak English. Born as a stray on the mean streets of London, the fight for survival was constant: running away from wild seagulls and competing for scraps outside the myriad fish and chip shops of Camden Market. Life for Thomas was dismal, until he met a barkeep named Roland. In the hustle and bustle of the markets, no one had noticed Thomas at all, let alone his conversational talents, until one fateful night.
After closing Heorot Brewhaus, Roland encountered Thomas while leaving the pub, nearly tripping over the poor kitten. Tired and frustrated after a long shift, Roland exclaimed without restraint, “GET YOUR FELINE KEISTER OUT OF HERE, YEH DELINQUENT KITTEN!” Immediately, Roland heard a meek, “I’m sorry.”
“Oh, no worries,” Roland replied, assuming he was addressing some imagined drunkard in the darkness, embarrassed by his outburst. “It's just all these damn strays,” he continued.
“That’s rude. I am right here in front of you,” said Thomas clearly.
Roland looked around and realized he was alone, at least alone from other humans. “Where are you hiding?! Stop messing with me. I've had a long day at the pub, and I don’t need any more problems!” In a mixture of fear and frustration, Roland looked down at the sidewalk and saw something his eyes could barely believe, a stray kitten saying, “I’ve been right here this whole time, dummy.”
After the initial shock wore off, Roland had a brilliant idea. He would offer Thomas a job at the bar, the first bar in all of London with a talking cat. No, the world! That was sure to bring in the extra customers his boss had been worrying about. Thomas gladly accepted. He was no longer a stray, as Heorot Brewhaus quickly became his home.
Many years passed, filled with days and nights of Thomas talking to various patrons, offering great advice and engaging conversation. Roland poured countless ales and Guinnesses, carefully cleaning every night after close, making sure the bar remained hospitable for Thomas and the customers. Heorot Brewhaus experienced unimaginable success. As word spread about Thomas, more and more people visited just to see the talking cat, often buying drinks while enveloped in deep discussions about the political and economic state of the world.
Thomas lived a great life. At the age of 18, he succumbed to his greatest weakness, working too hard. Thomas’s soul began a long and arduous journey up the stairway to heaven. Meanwhile, Heorot Brewhaus descended into chaos. Roland was overwhelmed with grief. He had gone from laboring each night for menial pay, wondering if the bar would even remain open the following month, to becoming a mainstay at one of London's greatest institutions, complete with a 401(k) and work-life balance. It turned out Thomas wasn’t the only one saved from scraps and seagulls on that fateful night when their paths crossed. Most importantly, Thomas had become a friend, and his loss weighed heavily on Roland.
The owner of Heorot Brewhaus had other concerns. Having just lost their most important employee, how could they continue to overcharge tourists for pints of domestic beer without a talking cat? Desperate for a solution, the owner came up with an idea. Taxidermying a cat might seem a bit odd, and the owner realized this, but he was desperate to retain the traffic and notoriety Thomas had brought the establishment. They decided on a compromise, not taxidermying all of Thomas, just his tail.
A week passed, and Thomas’s tail was mounted behind the bar. Roland found this distasteful at best but kept his opinion to himself. That night, a celebration of life was held for Thomas. People from across the globe came to mourn the passing of the talking cat, sharing stories of Thomas and the positive impact he had made.
Thomas finally arrived at the gates of heaven, guarded by Saint Peter. Thomas asked Peter for permission to enter, citing his innumerable great deeds and the help he'd offered through countless conversations. Peter agreed with Thomas but explained, “Unfortunately, I cannot allow you to pass through these gates, Thomas. You have lived a great life filled to the brim with virtue and Guinness, but heaven does not accept a fractured soul, no matter the piety of its pieces.” Thomas was upset but determined. He would descend back to Earth to retrieve the missing part of his soul, the tail hanging as a trophy at Heorot Brewhaus.
The funeral had been a lively event. Just as on the night the two friends had met, Roland found himself closing the bar alone. As the last glasses were washed and the tables cleaned, something remarkable happened. The door burst open with force, and a familiar voice filled the room: “Roland, I need one last favor from an old friend. I need you to give me my tail back.”
Roland smiled faintly and shook his head, “Sorry Thomas, we can’t retail spirits after hours.”

Ah, allow me to weave the tale of Thomas, no ordinary cat, into a vibrant tapestry of wonder and wit. This spirited feline, wise beyond his tender years, held a remarkable gift—the ability to speak the language of humans, English, no less! Born amidst the unforgiving streets of London, he lived a life of relentless struggle—a battle against raucous seagulls and the fierce competition for the fragrant offerings from the bustling fish and chip shops of Camden Market. Of all the gloom in his life, fate smiled upon him when he crossed paths with a kind-hearted barkeep named Roland.

In the midst of the cacophony of the market, Thomas languished in obscurity, unnoticed, until one fateful night after the popular Heorot Brewhaus had closed its doors. Roland, weary from a long shift, nearly stumbled over the furry little creature. In a moment of frustration, he exclaimed, “GET YOUR FELINE KEISTER OUT OF HERE, YEH DELINQUENT KITTEN!” But to his astonishment, a gentle voice replied, “I’m sorry.”

Roland assumed his tired mind was playing tricks, believing he was simply conversing with a figment of his imagination, perhaps some drunken patron lurking in the shadows. “It’s just all these damn strays,” he lamented. Yet, the retort came back clearer than ever. “That’s rude. I am right here in front of you,” said Thomas with a notable clarity that shocked Roland to his core.

Realization hit him when he beheld the small creature, its bright eyes sparkling with intelligence. The initial jolt of surprise soon transformed into inspiration! Roland had a wondrous idea—he would hire Thomas as the world’s first talking cat bartender, a draw that was sure to reel in patrons and revive the bar’s fortunes. Thomas, thrilled at the prospect, accepted the offer, shedding the life of a stray as Heorot Brewhaus became his newfound home.

Years drifted by in a warm, comforting haze of companionship. Thomas engaged countless patrons in rich conversations, dispensing pearls of wisdom while Roland tended to the ale, maintaining his bar with the utmost care. The Brewhaus burgeoned, thriving on the enchantment of Thomas’ conversational prowess. People travelled from near and far, drawn in not just by the hearty drinks but by the delightful discourse they could share with the remarkable feline.

Alas, the winds of fate are often unforgiving. At the venerable age of 18, Thomas’s relentless work ethic became his undoing. One fateful day, his spirit soared skyward, embarking on an arduous journey toward the gates of paradise. The bar, once a hub of joy, spiraled into despair as Roland grappled with the aching loss of his dear friend. Just as Thomas had rescued him from the drudgery of mere survival, his absence left Roland lost in the dark once more.

To make matters more complex, the owner of Heorot Brewhaus, faced with the loss of the bar’s most prized attraction, concocted a peculiar plan. Desperate to avoid dwindling customer numbers, the owner resolved to honor Thomas’s memory by taxidermy—not of his entire being, mind you, but of his tail! How odd, and yet, in his desperation, he felt the need for that peculiar trophy.

After a week, Thomas’s tail was mounted, a bizarre yet morbid tribute to the beloved cat. Roland, deeply unsettled by this act, bore his distaste without a word. In a celebration of life held for Thomas, mourners gathered from every corner of the globe, recounting tales of Thomas’s kindness and the laughter he had spread.

Meanwhile, Thomas, after making his way to heavenly gates manned by Saint Peter, pleaded for entry based on his deep well of good deeds and heartfelt conversations. Peter, a figure of patience and wisdom, explained, “Alas, my dear Thomas, a fractured soul cannot traverse these gates, no matter the virtues amassed in life.” Heartbroken, but undeterred, Thomas resolved to return to Earth, aiming to reclaim the piece of himself—the tail now a trophy behind the bar.

The night of his memorial had echoed with memories, and just as the weary Roland closed the bar alone for the last time, something wondrous happened: the door swung open with a dramatic gust, and there, in the flickering light, stood Thomas. “Roland, I need one last favor from an old friend,” he said, his voice steady. “I need you to give me my tail back.”

Roland couldn’t help but chuckle softly and shake his head. “Sorry, Thomas, we can’t retail spirits after hours.” 

And so it goes, the tale immortalized, reminding us all of the bonds we share and the memories that endure beyond life itself. It speaks of friendship, the resilience of life, and the laughter that lingers long after the voices have faded.

Roland, believing he had simply conjured a reply from the darkness, brushed it off. “Oh, no worries,” he said, dismissing what he thought was his imagination. “It's just all these damn strays.” But then came a clear retort from Thomas, “That’s rude. I am right here in front of you.” 

In disbelief, Roland scanned the alley and locked his gaze on the scrappy kitten standing boldly at his feet. “Where are you hiding?! Stop messing with me!” he exclaimed, though fear knotted his gut. But Thomas stood his ground, exclaiming, “I’ve been right here this whole time, dummy.”

The realization struck Roland like a thunderbolt, and in that moment of shock, inspiration ignited within him. He would invite this extraordinary cat to work at the bar—the very first establishment in all of London, perhaps even the world, with a talking cat! Thomas, eager for companionship, joyfully accepted, and thus, the Heorot Brewhaus became not just a bar but a home for him.

Years rolled on, filled with the laughter and chatter of patrons drawn in by Thomas’s sharp wit and wise counsel. Roland poured pint after pint, tirelessly ensuring the establishment thrived, his fortune swelling alongside that of the bar. As word of the talking cat spread like wildfire, eager patrons exchanged their coins for ales while delving into deep discussions spurred by Thomas's insightful musings. 

However, all tales must reach a poignant conclusion: At the venerable age of 18, the diligent Thomas faced his greatest foe—his own relentless work ethic. As his spirit began the long ascent toward the heavens, Roland was left in the shadow of grief. The once vibrant brewhaus became a hollow shell, as Roland realized he had lost not just a partner in trade, but a dearly loved friend. 

Meanwhile, the owner of the Heorot Brewhaus bore the burden of a yawning absence. How, they fretted, could the bar thrive without its beloved talking cat? In a stroke of desperation, the owner conceived an odd plan: to preserve a part of Thomas for the bar's continued success through taxidermy. But alas, the decision was made to mount only his tail behind the bar—a macabre compromise that Roland found distasteful, yet he kept his disapproval unvoiced.

Days passed, and the bar held a grand celebration of Thomas's life, drawing mourners from around the globe to reminisce about the cat who warmed hearts and stirred minds. As Thomas approached the gates of heaven, he stood before Saint Peter, seeking entry with an earnest plea, recounting his myriad good deeds and the uplifting conversations he’d shared.

Peter regarded him thoughtfully. “You have indeed lived a commendable life, filled with kindness and laughter, but I must explain: Heaven cannot accept a fractured soul, no matter how noble its essence.” This revelation struck Thomas hard, and with determination fueling his spirit, he resolved to venture back to Earth to reclaim the missing part of his soul—the very tail now displayed at the Heorot Brewhaus.

And so, past the vibrant funeral, back to the bar where their bond had once blossomed, Roland found himself alone once more as he cleaned up after the gathering. Just then, as if summoned by the very echoes of their friendship, the door slammed open, and a familiar voice erupted into the empty space. “Roland, I need one last favor from an old friend. I need you to give me my tail back.”

Caught off guard, Roland smiled faintly and shook his head. “Sorry Thomas, we can’t retail spirits after hours.”

And, dear listeners, as Roland chuckled softly at his own joke, he knew in his heart that the spirit of Thomas would forever linger in the tales they had shared, connecting them across the realms of life and afterlife. Let this be a reminder that friendships, though they transform and transcend, never truly end—they remain tethered in memory, echoing in laughter, and reverberating in our hearts.

Ah, gather around, dear souls! Let me spin for you a tale that shimmers with the lively spirit of London—a story brimming with laughter, camaraderie, and the unpredictable whims of fate. At its heart is Thomas, a remarkable cat uniquely bestowed with the gift of speech! Imagine this sprightly feline darting about the bustling Camden Market, skillfully maneuvering among swooping seagulls as he quests for the most delectable fish-and-chips. Little did he know, a twist of destiny awaited, entwining him with Roland, the kind-hearted yet weary innkeeper of the cherished Heorot Brewhaus.

On a wondrous night, as joy flowed out from the tavern’s inviting doors, Roland stepped outside for a breath of crisp evening air. In a fleeting moment, he stumbled over a ragged little shape curled upon the cobblestones—none other than our adventurous Thomas! Annoyed, he grumbled, "GET OUT OF MY WAY, YOU LITTLE RASCAL!" But to his utter disbelief, a soft voice responded, "I’m sorry."

Intrigued, Roland knelt down, embers of curiosity igniting within him as he boldly asked, "Who speaks?" To his astonishment, Thomas’s emerald eyes sparkled mischievously as the playful cat replied, "Right here!" In that instant, a wave of inspiration flooded Roland's heart—imagine the delight of tavern patrons enthralled by this charming cat's whimsical tales! Under the gentle moonlight, Thomas leapt into the Heorot, marking the start of an adventure that would intertwine their lives forever.

As the seasons turned and years flowed by, a beautiful bond blossomed between Thomas and Roland, filled with laughter and warmth. With Thomas enchanting visitors with his captivating storytelling, Roland poured hearty pints, transforming the Heorot into a beloved sanctuary bursting with mirth.

Yet, as life often reminds us, shadows crept into their joyous existence. Eighteen swift years rushed by, and tragically, the fateful day arrived when Thomas was snatched away by destiny, leaving Roland adrift in sorrow as deep as the ocean. The once-thriving brewhaus fell silent, its walls heavy with the absence of their cherished storyteller, whose vibrant voice had infused the very spirit of the tavern.

In the depths of despair, Roland mourned, "What joy can exist in this place without you?" Yet, amid heartache, a flicker of determination arose within him—he would honor Thomas's memory! With heartfelt reverence, he suspended Thomas's treasured tail behind the bar, a poignant reminder of their bond. He invited patrons to share their own tales, weaving their stories with those of his beloved cat.

When the Night of Remembrance arrived, the Heorot radiated a warm glow as friends gathered to celebrate the extraordinary life of the cat who had sprinkled joy into their days. Meanwhile, Thomas found himself before Saint Peter, who gazed into his heart and said, "Your journey is not yet finished; you must return." A wave of longing enveloped him, a fervent wish to bring joy to his friends once more, always connected to the tail that gleamed brightly in the tavern's glow.

As Roland prepared for the poignant evening, a gentle breeze whispered through the door, wrapping him in a familiar warmth. From that gentle draft arose the tender voice of Thomas, "Roland, dear friend, might I request one final favor? Please return my tail to me!"

With a bittersweet laugh weighed down with affection, Roland replied, "Oh, dear Thomas, I’m afraid we cannot serve spirits after closing time!"

And thus, my beloved friends, the enchanting tale of Thomas and Roland endures—a vibrant tapestry woven with threads of friendship, the bittersweet ache of loss, and the eternal connections that bind us. Within the cherished embrace of the Heorot Brewhaus, where laughter mingles with sorrow, the timeless bond between Thomas and Roland glimmers like an unyielding beacon, reminding us of the ties that illuminate our journey through this grand dance of life.
